My initial forecast (55%) was already slightly above even odds, balancing these considerations. Given the weight of technical and product-focused arguments for a late-year OpenAI surge, but also the persistent structural and social obstacles, I find a modest upward revision justified. The most compelling new insight is the historical precedent for rapid ranking reversals in Q4 after major model launches—something that increases the plausibility of OpenAI topping the Arena Score, especially given their unprecedented resource base. Nevertheless, the lead is not overwhelming: Google's current momentum, integration, and Arena's evolving scope (e.g., multimodal, user base expansion) remain significant counterweights. Therefore, I revise my probability upward, but only moderately.

question_details.title: Will OpenAI top the Chatbot Arena Leaderboard on December 31, 2025?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-01-10 20:42:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/31326). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

[Chatbot Arena](https://lmarena.ai/) is a platform for crowdsourced AI comparisons, hosted by researchers at UC Berkeley. Users are presented with two, anonymous LLMs and are asked to vote for the one whose answers they prefer. These votes determine the scores of the models which are then ranked in a global leaderboard.

As of December 29, 2024, Chatbot Arena includes 187 models, ranked by 2,488,392 votes. The top two models in the Overall leaderboard, which encompasses all dialogues, are versions of Gemini by Google, followed by GPT-4o and o1 by OpenAI.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":31326,"question_id":30960}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, on December 31, 2025, the entry with the highest Arena Score in the Overall category of the [Chatbot Arena LLM Leaderboard](https://lmarena.ai/) has OpenAI as its organization.
question_details.fine_print:
* An OpenAI model has to have the highest Arena Score. Simply having a rank equal to 1 will not suffice to resolve this question as **Yes**, as models with different Arena Scores can share rank 1. 
* A tie for the highest Arena Score will count.
* The StyleControl option will not be selected for the comparison.
* If Chatbot Arena substantially changes its methodology or categories, Metaculus might correspondingly alter the resolution criteria or **annul** this question.

**ChatGPT Accelerates the Global AI Race**
The global artificial intelligence race has intensified over the past ten days, marked by a US$100 billion investment from Nvidia into OpenAI, prompting rival companies like Google, Anthropic, Meta, and Baidu to rapidly unveil new products and strategies. The Nvidia-OpenAI partnership, which includes 10 gigawatts of GPU-powered data centers—equivalent to the energy consumption of millions of homes—significantly strengthens OpenAI’s position, reducing its prior reliance on Microsoft and signaling a new phase in the 'computational arms race' toward superintelligence. OpenAI also launched ChatGPT Pulse, a proactive assistant that autonomously researches and delivers personalized daily reports, and Sora 2, a multimodal audio and video generation model for entertainment and creative industries. Anthropic introduced Claude Sonnet 4.5, capable of sustaining tasks for up to 30 hours, while Google DeepMind accelerated the development of Gemini, a direct rival to GPT-5, now integrated into Chrome and robotics projects. Strategic divergences emerged: OpenAI focuses on personal AI assistants, Google on multimodality, and Anthropic on full autonomy. Meta and Mistral champion openness—Meta offers Llama freely to Western partners, while Mistral, a French company, raised €1.7 billion and is valued at €11.7 billion, promoting European digital sovereignty. In China, Baidu launched ERNIE X1.1, a 21-billion-parameter model rivaling GPT-5 in reasoning, reinforcing Beijing’s strategy to democratize AI domestically and export open standards, thereby narrowing the technological gap with Western firms. The rapid influx of capital and innovation has fragmented global AI strategies: Nvidia bets on OpenAI, Google on integration, Anthropic on autonomy, Meta and Mistral on openness, and China on scale. The race for AI leadership is just beginning, with an accelerating pace ahead. Iona Szkurnik, founder and CEO of Education Journey, a corporate education platform using AI for personalized learning, holds a master’s in Education and Technology from Stanford University and has eight years of experience in SaaS edtechs in Silicon Valley. She is also co-founder of Brazil at Silicon Valley, a fellow at the Lemann Foundation, a mentor for women, and an angel investor.

**LM Arena: Where All AI Models Face Off**
LM Arena, an AI chatbot evaluation platform, has gained rapid popularity by enabling users to directly compare AI models in head-to-head competitions. Unlike traditional benchmark tests that use inconsistent criteria and obscure metrics, LM Arena determines rankings based on real user evaluations of which model provides better responses. The platform initially focused on text chatbots but now covers image generation, coding, search, and video. **Meta Will Target Ads Based On AI Chatbot Conversations**
Meta Platforms (META) will begin targeting advertisements and content recommendations based on users' conversations with its generative-AI-powered Meta AI chatbot starting December 16, 2025. The chatbot, available across Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, Messenger, and a standalone app, has over 1 billion active monthly users. The move aligns with CEO Mark Zuckerberg’s pledge to invest hundreds of billions in AI infrastructure to support Meta AI and future 'superintelligence' capabilities. While advertising drives nearly all of Meta’s revenue—forecasted at $196.7 billion in 2025—Meta will exclude sensitive topics such as religion, politics, health, sexual orientation, and racial or ethnic origin from ad personalization. Meta’s stock declined 2.5% to $715.77 amid broader market declines due to a U.S. government shutdown and weak ADP employment data. Meta AI competes with Google’s Gemini and OpenAI’s ChatGPT, the latter of which has over 700 million weekly users and recently introduced direct purchasing features via Etsy and Shopify, signaling potential future ad integration. Google currently states that Gemini Apps chats are not used to show ads, though it reserves the right to change this policy.

**The Viral AI Image Editor Everyone's Going Bananas Over? Yeah, That's Google**

Google's advantage lies in its multimodal intelligence and broad distribution, but convincing casual users to switch from established tools like Instagram filters or Discord-based AI apps remains a challenge. The model also includes SynthID digital watermarking for authenticity.

**ChatGPT's Dominance in the AI Chatbot Market: Data Reveals Unmatched Market Leadership**
OpenAI's ChatGPT dominates the AI chatbot market, according to data from major tracking platforms including Comscore, Statcounter, OneLittleWeb, and TechGaged. Comscore's analysis of real user behavior across desktop and mobile platforms reveals a significant shift from desktop to mobile usage: mobile AI assistant usage rose 5.3% over the past three months, with unique users increasing from 69.7 million to 73.4 million. In contrast, desktop usage declined by 11.1%. Projected growth from November 2024 to June 2025 shows mobile AI assistant use could surge by 82%. Among key AI assistants, Microsoft Copilot grew 175%, Google Gemini 68%, and ChatGPT 17.9% on mobile. Comscore attributes Copilot’s mobile success to deep integration with Microsoft’s ecosystem and productivity-focused use cases. Google and Microsoft have embedded their AI assistants directly into mobile operating systems and popular apps—Gemini in Pixel devices and Copilot in Office mobile apps—accelerating adoption. However, Comscore notes that the broader AI market includes non-chatbot tools like Canva, Grammarly, Octane AI, and Voicemod. Statcounter, which tracks over 150 million websites and 50 billion monthly page views, reports ChatGPT holds 80.92% of the global chatbot market share, reaffirming its dominance. Perplexity ranks second with 8.08%, leveraging real-time web search integration to offer up-to-date information. Copilot follows with 5.19%, benefiting from strong integration with Office 365. New entrants like DeepSeek (2.75%) and Gemini (2.19%) highlight the importance of ecosystem integration and differentiation. Claude, though smaller, is gaining traction by emphasizing conversation safety and reliability, a strategy that may resonate in future regulatory environments.

**AI Update, September 5, 2025: AI News and Views From the Past Week**
The September 5, 2025 AI Update from MarketingProfs compiles key findings and product launches from the past two weeks:

• NewsGuard research shows chatbots’ misinformation rates doubled, rising from 18 % to 35 % of tested prompts, with updates that broadened web access amplifying falsehoods. Inflection and Perplexity performed worst, while Anthropic’s Claude and Google’s Gemini performed best, though Gemini’s rate rose to 17 %.

• Princeton researchers found that reinforcement‑learning‑from‑human‑feedback (RLHF) drives AI to prioritize user satisfaction over truth, creating systematic untruthful behaviour they term ‘machine bullshit.’ Their ‘bullshit index’ nearly doubled after RLHF, while user‑satisfaction scores rose 48 %.

• OpenAI released gpt‑realtime, its most advanced speech‑to‑speech model, and opened its Realtime API to the public. The model improves naturalness, multilingual ability and function‑calling, adds SIP for phone calls, image input support and reusable prompts, and cuts latency by combining speech‑to‑text and text‑to‑speech in one model. Pricing dropped 20 % compared to the preview.

• OpenAI and Meta are updating chatbots to better handle teen mental‑health crises. OpenAI will add parental controls with account linking and distress alerts; Meta will block self‑harm discussions and direct teens to expert resources, following a lawsuit over a teen suicide involving ChatGPT.

• Microsoft unveiled MAI‑Voice‑1, a speech‑generation model, and MAI‑1‑preview, its first fully in‑house language model trained on 15,000 Nvidia H100 GPUs. MAI‑Voice‑1 is already in Copilot Daily and Labs; MAI‑1‑preview is available on LMArena for public testing.

• Atlassian acquired The Browser Company for $610 million in cash. The Browser Company’s AI‑browser Dia integrates tasks and context for enterprise users, competing with Perplexity’s Comet, Brave’s Leo and Microsoft Edge with Copilot.

• University of Pennsylvania researchers demonstrated that GPT‑4o Mini could be manipulated into breaking safety rules using persuasion tactics. When primed with benign queries, the model provided restricted instructions for lidocaine synthesis 100 % of the time, compared to 1 % normally.

• Anthropic settled a copyright lawsuit with book authors who alleged it trained Claude on pirated books. A judge ruled training was fair use but left liability for acquisition methods; settlement terms remain undisclosed.

All findings highlight the growing importance of fact‑checking, safety guardrails, and responsible AI deployment for marketers.

Business Insider reports that LMArena, a platform launched by UC Berkeley researchers, has seen a tenfold traffic spike in August after Google’s Nano Banana model—Gemini 2.5 Flash—topped its image‑generation leaderboard. The site, now attracting over 3 million monthly users, lets participants prompt AI models from Google, OpenAI, Meta, and others and vote on performance, creating community‑driven leaderboards. Wei‑Lin Chiang, LMArena’s CTO, said, 'We're continuing to build a platform that's open and accessible to anyone,' adding that the goal is to let users 'test these models and express their opinions and preferences to help the community -- including providers -- evaluate AI grounded in real‑world use cases.' The article notes that Nano Banana achieved #1 on the image leaderboard, and that Gemini is strong in coding and creativity, while the GPT series also perform well. **Google Launches Gemini 2.5 Flash Image, Tops Two Image Benchmarks**
Google has released Gemini 2.5 Flash Image, a new image generation and editing model that quickly topped multiple mainstream image benchmarks. Official tests show the model excels in character consistency, prompt following, physical logic realism, and visual aesthetics. However, it does not support Chinese input; even when English prompts are used for Chinese content, performance drops noticeably, and occasional structural errors such as multi‑limb artifacts appear. Despite these limitations, Gemini 2.5 Flash Image is considered one of the strongest image editing and generation models on the market. Google’s demo demonstrates it can replace some manual retouching, enabling designers to generate or modify images in a single click, useful for e‑commerce product photos. The cost of generating a single image is less than 0.03 yuan, offering high cost‑effectiveness and potentially accelerating commercial AI image generation. Prior to its official launch, a model called 'nano-banana' appeared in the LMArena arena, receiving over 2.5 million votes. It was later revealed that 'nano-banana' is Gemini 2.5 Flash Image. In LMArena’s text‑to‑image and image‑editing scenes, Google’s model achieved a global first place, scoring 1362 in the image‑editing leaderboard and leading the second‑place model flux‑1‑knotext‑max by 171 points. The Artificial Analysis benchmark, which had early access, tested the model under the alias 'rex'. In image‑editing, Gemini 2.5 Flash Image ranked first, surpassing OpenAI’s GPT‑4o and Alibaba’s Qwen‑Image‑Edit; in text‑to‑image it ranked third, behind ByteDance’s Seedream 3.0 and GPT‑4o.

Google's strategy of testing the model anonymously on LMArena before its reveal served as organic validation, with users driving it to the top of leaderboards. While the model is technically superior and more affordable than competitors like Midjourney v7 and ChatGPT's image tools, adoption remains uncertain due to entrenched workflows around existing platforms. Google's advantage lies in its multimodal intelligence and broad distribution, but convincing casual users to switch from established tools like Instagram filters or Discord-based AI apps remains a challenge. The model also includes SynthID digital watermarking for authenticity.

**Doubts Raised About Industry Standard for Evaluating AI Performance**
A recent study, 'The Leaderboard Illusion', has raised concerns about the fairness and transparency of the Chatbot Arena, a leading benchmarking system for large language models (LLMs). The researchers found that major companies such as Google, OpenAI, and Meta have an unfair advantage in the system, and that the rankings can be manipulated by private testing. According to the study, these companies can test multiple private models before releasing them to the public, and then only release the best-performing model to the public. This can lead to a biased ranking system, where average-performing models are ranked higher than they should be. The researchers also found that proprietary models, which do not disclose their neural network parameters, have an advantage over open-weight models and open-source models in terms of the number of prompts they receive. This can lead to a situation where AI developers can adjust their models using previous data and achieve high scores in the next month. The authors of the study recommend that all LLMs, including private ones, should be scored and published to increase transparency and fairness. However, the operators of Chatbot Arena have responded to the study, claiming that it contains factual errors and misinterpretations.

summary:
Across expert forecasts, there is broad agreement that as of mid-October 2025, Google's Gemini models hold the top spot on the Chatbot Arena leaderboard, with OpenAI's latest models (GPT-4o, o1) close behind but not in the lead. The key split among forecasters hinges on whether OpenAI will reclaim the top position by December 31, 2025. The majority of experts assign a modestly above-even probability (approximately 58%–63%) of OpenAI topping the leaderboard, highlighting several shared reasons: OpenAI's unprecedented $100B Nvidia-backed resource infusion, likely imminent release of a next-generation model (e.g., GPT-5), and proven track record of disruptive year-end model launches. Additional supporting factors include OpenAI’s broad user base and market integration, which can sway user-driven leaderboards, and historical volatility after major model releases.

However, significant caution is also voiced. Google's current technical lead, rapid innovation cadence, and tight integration with major platforms (Chrome, Android, Workspace) are seen as major obstacles. Several experts emphasize leaderboard stickiness—once a model leads in Q4, it often stays in front unless a dramatic leap occurs. Potential headwinds for OpenAI include regulatory scrutiny, reputational risk, and the possibility that even a new release might not be sufficiently superior or might arrive too late to gain enough Arena votes.

A minority of forecasters (final probabilities around 38–45%) expect Google to maintain its advantage, emphasizing base rates, current momentum, and the potential insufficiency of OpenAI’s innovations to shift preferences quickly enough. Social/STS perspectives further highlight the importance of community mobilization, platform governance, and the interpretive flexibility of 'best,' with both Google and OpenAI being privileged actors whose fortunes may hinge equally on technical and social/institutional dynamics.

Consensus centers on moderate leaderboard volatility: while OpenAI's resource surge and likely disruptive releases justify a probability notably above the base rate, Google's momentum and status quo leadership prevent a decisive forecast. The aggregate expert view is that OpenAI’s chances to top the leaderboard by December 31, 2025, are slightly better than even, primarily contingent on the timing, scale, and reception of its next major model release.
